DOCNAME: CASE OF BIJELIC v. MONTENEGRO AND SERBIA
CONCLUSION: Remainder inadmissible;Violation of P1-1;Pecuniary and non-pecuniary damage - award
JUDGES: Françoise Tulkens;Ireneu Cabral Barreto;Nebojša Vučinić;Nona Tsotsoria;Vladimiro Zagrebelsky
TEXT: CARDINAL . The first , second and third applicants were born in DATE and DATE , respectively , and currently live in GPE , GPE .
CARDINAL . The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . The first applicant , her husband and the other CARDINAL applicants were holders of a specially protected tenancy concerning a flat in GPE ( nosioci odnosno korisnici stanarskog prava ) , GPE , where they lived .
CARDINAL . In DATE the first applicant and her husband divorced and the former was granted custody of the other CARDINAL applicants .

CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant obtained a decision from ORG ( PERSON u GPE ) declaring her the sole holder of the specially protected tenancy on the family ’s flat . In addition , her former husband ( “ the respondent ” ) was ordered to vacate the flat DATE from DATE when the decision became final .
CARDINAL . On DATE the decision of ORG was upheld on appeal by ORG ( ORG u GPE ) and thereby became final .
CARDINAL . Given that the respondent did not comply with the court order to vacate the flat , on DATE the first applicant instituted a formal judicial enforcement procedure before ORG .
CARDINAL . The enforcement order was issued on DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiffs attempted to evict the respondent together with his new wife and minor children but the eviction was adjourned because he threatened to use force .
CARDINAL . On DATE they tried again , this time assisted by the police , but apparently the planned eviction was adjourned for the same reason .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant bought the flat and became its owner .

CARDINAL . On DATE the bailiffs and the police once again failed to evict the respondent who kept threatening the first applicant in their presence and bore arms on his person . There also appear to have been additional weapons , ammunition and even a bomb in the flat at the time . The police took the respondent to their station but released him shortly afterwards without pressing charges .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE another CARDINAL scheduled evictions failed , the latter due to the “ respondent ’s request for the provision of social assistance ” in respect of his minor children .
CARDINAL . On DATE the first applicant gifted the flat to the second and third applicants .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE , respectively , another CARDINAL scheduled evictions failed .
CARDINAL . On DATE ORG informed the first applicant that ORG had committed to enforce the eviction order before DATE .
CARDINAL . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE another CARDINAL scheduled evictions failed .
CARDINAL . In the meantime , on CARDINAL DATE , ORG ( Direkcija za nekretnine ) issued a formal decision recognising the second and the third applicants as the new owners of the flat in question .

CARDINAL . In DATE another eviction was attempted but failed . In the presence of police officers , fire fighters , paramedics , bailiffs and the enforcement judge herself , as well as his wife and their children , the respondent threatened to blow up the entire flat . His neighbours also seem to have opposed the eviction , some of them apparently going so far as to physically confront the police .
CARDINAL . NORP Throughout DATE the first applicant complained to numerous ORG bodies about the non - enforcement of the judgment rendered in her favour , but to no avail .
CARDINAL . On DATE another scheduled enforcement failed because the respondent had threatened to “ spill blood ” rather than be evicted .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE , respectively , the enforcement judge sent letters to ORG , seeking assistance .

CARDINAL . On DATE the enforcement judge was told , at a meeting with the police , that the eviction in question was too dangerous to be carried out , that the respondent could blow up the entire building by means of a remote control device , and that the officers themselves were not equipped to deal with a situation of this sort . The police therefore proposed that the applicants be provided with another flat instead of the CARDINAL in question .
CARDINAL . On DATE the enforcement judge urged ORG to secure the kind of police assistance needed for the respondent ’s ultimate eviction .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second applicant , on her own behalf and on behalf of the third applicant , authorised the first applicant to sell the flat in question .
CARDINAL . On DATE the second and third applicants authorised the first applicant , inter alia , to represent them in the enforcement proceedings .

CARDINAL . The applicants maintain that the gift contract of DATE ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) and the said powers of attorney were submitted to the enforcement court . The first applicant was therefore the second and third applicants’ legal representative in the enforcement proceedings .
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of this Charter read as follows :

The Member ORG which ... [ breaks away ] ... shall not inherit the right to international legal personality , and any disputable issues shall be regulated separately between the successor ORG and the newly independent ORG . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of this LAW read as follows :
“ The human and minority rights guaranteed under this Charter shall be directly regulated , secured and protected by the constitutions , laws and policies of the Member GPE . ”
CARDINAL . The relevant part of this ORG reads as follows :

“ The domestic legal system offers no legal remedy against violations of the right to a hearing within a reasonable time , which is why the courts in GPE have no jurisdiction to rule in respect of claims seeking non - pecuniary damages caused by a breach of this right . Any person who considers himself a victim of a violation of this right may therefore lodge an application with ORG , within DATE as of the adoption of the final judgment by the domestic courts .

[ When asked to rule in respect of the compensation claims referred to above ] ... the courts in GPE must refuse jurisdiction ... and declare ... [ them ] ... inadmissible ( pursuant to LAW para . CARDINAL of LAW ) . ”

CARDINAL . This Act provides , under certain circumstances , for the possibility to have lengthy proceedings expedited , as well as an opportunity for the claimants to be awarded compensation therefor .

CARDINAL . DATE , in particular , provides that this Act shall be applied retroactively to all proceedings as of DATE , but that the duration of proceedings before that date shall also be taken into account .
CARDINAL . This Act entered into force on DATE , but contained no reference to the applications involving procedural delay already lodged with the ORG .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to LAW the police are obliged to assist other ORG bodies in the enforcement of their decisions if there is physical resistance or such resistance may reasonably be expected .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that the enforcement court is obliged to proceed urgently .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , if needed , the bailiff may request police assistance ; should the police fail to provide such assistance , the enforcement court shall inform thereof the Minister of ORG , the Government , or the competent parliamentary body .
